gameMechanics.title: Game Mechanics
gameMechanics.intro: D-GRE Stock Exchange is a realistic stock market game. Trade 16 stocks with virtual money, compete against AI players, and try to grow your portfolio. Prices update each trading cycle -- the game is played in rounds.
gameMechanics.durationIntro: Choose how long you want to play before the game starts:
gameMechanics.durationUnlimited: Unlimited -- play as long as you want, no ranking at the end.
gameMechanics.speedIntro: You can change the speed during the game:
gameMechanics.autoPause: The game automatically pauses when you open the trade panel, loan dialog, settings, or this help screen. It resumes when you close them.
gameMechanics.endScreen: When time runs out, you see a ranking against all virtual players. Your net worth is calculated as cash + stock value - debt + short position profit/loss.
gameMechanics.previewHotkey: Press Alt+R at any time to preview the current standings without ending the game.

loans.title: Loan System
loans.intro: You can borrow money to increase your buying power. But be careful -- loans cost interest and must be repaid on time!
loans.creditLine: Your credit line is based on your stock holdings. Large-cap stocks (market cap > $200B) count as 70% of their value, small/mid-cap stocks as 50%. Cash does not count as collateral. The maximum credit is 2.5x the recommended amount.
loans.duration: Each loan runs for {{minLoanDuration}} to {{maxLoanDuration}} cycles. When it expires, the full amount is automatically repaid from your cash.
loans.interest: The base interest rate is {{baseInterestRate}}% and is charged every {{interestChargeCycles}} cycles. The rate increases if you use a lot of your credit line (+1% at 50% utilization, +3% at 75%) or trade aggressively (+2%). Conservative traders get a 1% discount.
loans.fees: A {{originationFee}}% origination fee is deducted when you take a loan. If you repay early, a {{earlyRepaymentFee}}% early repayment fee applies.
loans.creditScore: Your credit score ranges from 0 to 100 and starts at 50. Repaying loans on time improves it, while overdue payments lower it. A higher score means better interest rates on future loans.
loans.multipleLoans: You can have up to {{maxLoans}} loans at the same time. However, each additional loan adds +1% to the interest rate.

trading.title: Trading
trading.intro: You can trade stocks using different order types. Each order is processed after one trading cycle. A {{feePercent}}% transaction fee applies to every trade.
trading.marketOrder: Buys or sells at the current market price. Executes after one cycle. A small cash buffer is reserved to account for price fluctuations.
trading.limitOrder: Buy at or below / sell at or above a price you set. You choose the validity period (default: {{orderValidity}} cycles). If the price condition is not met in time, the order expires.
trading.stopBuy: Triggers a market buy when the price rises to your stop price. Useful for buying into an upward breakout.
trading.stopLoss: Triggers a market sell when the price falls to your stop price. Used to automatically limit your losses.
trading.stopBuyLimit: A two-stage order: first triggers at the stop price, then only executes if the limit price is also met. Gives you more control than a regular stop buy.
trading.stopLossLimit: A two-stage order: triggers at the stop price, then only executes if the limit price is met. Prevents selling at an unexpectedly low price.
trading.shortSellingIntro: Short selling lets you bet on falling prices. You borrow shares, sell them immediately, and hope to buy them back later at a lower price.
trading.shortHowItWorks: You sell borrowed shares at the current price. If the price drops, you buy them back cheaper and keep the difference as profit. If the price rises, you lose money.
trading.shortMargin: Opening a short requires {{initialMargin}}% of the position value as collateral, locked from your credit line. You must maintain at least {{maintenanceMargin}}% at all times.
trading.shortBorrowFees: You pay {{baseBorrowFee}}% per cycle to borrow shares. If more than 50% of a stock's float is shorted, the fee is multiplied by {{hardToBorrowMultiplier}}x (hard to borrow).
trading.shortMarginCall: If your collateral drops below {{maintenanceMargin}}%, you receive a margin call. You then have {{marginCallGraceCycles}} cycles to add margin or close the position. Otherwise, it is forcibly liquidated.
trading.buyToCover: To close a short position, you buy back the borrowed shares. This is called 'buy to cover'. Any profit or loss is realized at that point.

economy.title: Economy
economy.intro: The game simulates a dynamic economy with market indices, sector relationships, and changing economic phases.
economy.mainIndex: The main index tracks the weighted performance of all 16 stocks. It starts at 10,000 points. Larger companies have more influence on the index value.
economy.sectorIndices: Four sector indices (D-GREX Tek, Fin, Ind, Raw) show the performance of Technology, Finance, Industrial, and Commodities. Use them to spot which sectors are strong or weak.
economy.sectorDynamicsIntro: Stocks in the same industry influence each other, just like in real markets.
economy.correlation: Stocks in the same sector share a common trend. When one tech stock rises, other tech stocks often follow. This momentum builds and fades over multiple cycles.
economy.interSector: Sectors also affect each other. Strong financial stocks can support tech and industrial (through credit). Rising industrial values increase commodity demand. But expensive commodities can burden industry.
economy.marketMakerIntro: A virtual market maker acts as the counterparty for all your trades. Its inventory level affects trading conditions.
economy.inventory: The color bar shows inventory: green (80-120%) is normal, yellow (50-80%) is low, red (<50%) is critical, and blue (>120%) is excess.
economy.dynamicSpread: Low market maker inventory means a higher spread (more expensive to trade). High inventory means a lower spread (cheaper to trade).
economy.rebalancing: Each cycle, the market maker's inventory moves 1% back toward normal. Extreme values recover over time.
economy.spread: The spread is the difference between the buy price and the sell price of a stock. Currently {{spreadPercent}}%. This is a hidden trading cost on every transaction, in addition to the {{feePercent}}% transaction fee.
economy.slippage: Large orders can move the price. The 'effective price' shown before you trade includes this price impact so you know your actual cost.
economy.fearGreed: A sentiment gauge from 0 to 100. 0-25 = Extreme Fear, 26-45 = Fear, 46-55 = Neutral, 56-75 = Greed, 76-100 = Extreme Greed. It reflects the overall mood of the market.
economy.marketPhasesIntro: The economy cycles through six phases that affect stock prices, volatility, and trading costs:
economy.phaseProsperity: Prosperity -- Stable growth, moderate volatility. A good time for steady gains.
economy.phaseBoom: Boom -- High growth, rising prices. Profits are easy, but a correction may follow.
economy.phaseConsolidation: Consolidation -- Uncertainty, mixed signals. The market decides its next direction.
economy.phasePanic: Panic -- Sharp drops, high volatility. Prices can fall rapidly.
economy.phaseRecession: Recession -- Prolonged downturn, low prices. Can be an opportunity for bargain hunters.
economy.phaseRecovery: Recovery -- The market turns around. Prices start climbing again from low levels.

tips.title: Tips for Success
tips.tip1: Diversify across sectors -- don't put all your money into one stock or industry.
tips.tip2: Watch the charts and sector indices before buying. Look for trends and momentum.
tips.tip3: Use stop-loss orders to automatically limit your losses if a stock drops.
tips.tip4: Start with small positions to learn how the market works before investing heavily.
tips.tip5: Watch sector momentum -- when one sector rises, related sectors may follow.

help.title: What is Short Selling?
help.description: In short selling, you sell borrowed shares that you don't own. You're betting that the price will fall so you can buy them back cheaper later.
help.margin: You must post collateral (margin) from your credit line.
help.risk: Warning: The loss potential is theoretically unlimited, as prices can rise indefinitely.
help.fees: Borrow fees are charged per cycle for borrowed shares.
